reviewText:
A fragmented player base brought on by new year to year versions instead of add-ons to a base game.

A weak, difficult, and time wasting multiplayer experience brought on by said fragmentation and lack of basic functions like rank/matchmaking or even the simple ability to add someone to your steam friend's list while in game. This in addition to the general problem of online games being invisible to the player or knowing how many people are online playing at a given time - thus giving the impression of a dead multiplayer experience. Hell you can't even vote to restart a multiplayer match in-game that you might have drawn no lands in.

Confusing, overpriced DLC that often ends with people not knowing what they have bought, have already, or should have and thus ends with a multitude of complaint threads on these forums.

Slow UI, slow load/boot up, problems with card selection/assignments, & genreal bugs that seem to never be fixed year to year as one game is thrown out for the next.

This game has now 4 editions 2011,2012,2013,2014. The consistency between all versions seems to be a lack of attentiveness to increasing value to the basic player experience through debugging and improved multiplayer funcionality while adding as many ways to fleece the player of their money.

This combination of problems diminishes intrest year over year and will eventually lead to a product few want because those potentially interested have already had some form of irritation or negative experience with a past iteration of it.

The future is dim for a product that adds little - if any - value, year to year, while holding fast to the mountain of mistakes in its past.

Buyer beware.

reviewText:
If you've not played Magic in over a decade and want to tap some mana, this may just be the game you want to pick up. Here, you get a number of decks to play with, several modes and styles of play including multiplayer.

Things to keep in mind:
You won't find cards from the early era of magic you may recall from ages past. Alpha, beta, The Dark, Arabian Nights? Unlimited, & 3rd edtion? Not here. What you will find are a selection of decks from moderan 2013 era magic. What matters however is that you are given numerous ways to play the game and a number of various decks to mess around with.

You can buy this with a number of unlocks set, or with all cards unlocked. The locked variant might be for you if you enjoy the challenge of unlocking cards and the related achievement pleasure that can be had from unlocking. If you just want to play with cards, as many as you can get your mits on (without grinding) - you may want the 'Complete' edition.

At worst, in this release you can't build decks from an entirely raw ensemble of cards. You can however heavily modify the numerous decks that you are given. Most of these decks have anywhere from 30 to 40 specific deck limited extra cards that can be added or used to replace default deck setups to modify your style of play. Despite these official limitations of the 2013 M:tG game, there is actually something of a modding scene. Google for mods and you may just stumble into what you want if you really want to build decks from scratch / have minor game play bugs fixed.

A very minor user specific issue that can be disabled: Foil cards. IRL they're entertaining and in the game you can have them too. Yet they're animated and constantly glimmer. The constant animation can become a little irritating, turning a novelty special card into a literal headache. Fortunately, - the game has an option to remove the appearance of foil on all foil cards.

So, all in all this is a solidly entertaining version of Magic to mess around with on a computer. Be it offline multiplayer locally, online multiplayer, or in single player vs. AI's of varying difficulties.

reviewText: Riding on the success of DotP 2012's improvements, the 2013 release introduces revamped decks, a new unlock system, and a new game mode. While 2013 has less decks available (16 versus last year's 19), they are overall more accessible for quick play because of the 10 promo unlocks provided post-release. The decks are also more balanced in power overall because you aren't locked out of the best cards anymore. However, this is a double-edged sword; While you can unlock a total of 40 cards per deck, many of them are dups and you can only unlock one at a time. To put this into perspective, beating the first campaign (the longest in the game) will unlock 26 cards.\n\nWhile I enjoyed the difficult challenges (the hardest challenges of the DotP games in my opinion), this game is riddled with issues that will never get fixed or improved since the devs have moved onto their next yearly release. Locking out all but two decks at the start is a terrible way to introduce new players to MTG, especially considering the target market for these games. The one new game mode, Planechase, is only worth playing with friends; The AI is terrible at it, seeming to attack and roll the planar die randomly. Despite being marketed towards new and casual players, this game can only be recommended for experienced MTG players because of the unlock systems and frustration with non-human Planechase.

Magic 2013 was... underwhelming. While I appreciate all the new cards that were added, the experience as a whole felt less interesting than Magic 2012

Fortunately I was able to unlock cards this time around. Given the sheer number of decks, they really should have awarded at least two cards per battle. 30 battles per deck is just a horrible time sink, especially when it's not as fun as it used to be. I'm also starting to wish they had an option to turn off ALL animations. If I'm going to be grinding a long-♥♥♥ game, I don't want to see every card taking 5-10 seconds to play.

Sadly Archenemy mode is gone, and 2-headed giant only exists in custom games. I actually found both of those fun. In its place is Planechase mode which... *shudder*. Every round you wait for 3 CPUs to take their turns and they spin that atrocious dice over and over again. It's just... kill me now. Every time.

To the game's credit, decks felt more balanced overall. There's some strategy involved where some decks fare much better versus others, instead of a one-size-fits-all deck, but I kind of miss the feeling of overpoweredness from the previous game. The puzzles are still fun too.

Overall it's a distinctly inferior game compared to 2012. On its own, only average. I'll rate it 6/10. It makes me wish I was playing the last one.

A much needed upgrade over the 2012 version.  Magic DotP 2013 offers some much needed multiplayer variety.  Two headed giant, Planechase, and just playin multiplayer with up to 4 players add a new twist of fun.  Still lacking a full deck editor, there is a wide variety of preconstructed decks available and you can customize up to 30 cards in each of them as you win games and unlock new cards.  For a small fee, you can unlock entire decks to speed up the process.

The biggest downfall is the computer AI in single player.  Set teh difficulty too low and the computer plays like a complete newb.  Misplaying and skipping obvious combos.  Set the difficulty higher and the AI alwasy gets taht one card they need to stop whatever combo you are trying to pull off.  It's a little more than luck when the AI gets the exact card it needs out of its 60 card deck to counter the exact combo you are trying to pull off every time.

Only stomach the single player to unlock things that you want, if you don't want to spend the $1 to unlock a whole deck faster.  Stick to the multi-player if you want to have any real fun with this game.  The decks are nothing spectacular, but against each other they are fun enough to enjoy a good game.  The interface was designed for console games and is a little clunky at times, but manageable.  It can be a lot of fun if you have friends to play it with, and is an excellent tool for showing new players the basics.

Magic: The gathering – Duels of the Planewalkers2013 is a fun competitive card game to play with friends. Especially when there are four players in the game as it makes it a whole lot more dynamic and you won’t necessary loose just because you got badly RNG’d from the start.

The game consists of a Champaign that works pretty well where you will fight each deck to unlock them. There are also encounters such as fighting the hydra. Each encounter has a different touch to them, such as the hydra it gains attack/health for each turn.
When you have beaten the game you unlock the revenge campaign that upper the difficulty if you found the first campaign too easy.
There is also a challenge mod (that actually is challenging!) where you are presented by different scenarios and have to win the game within a set number of rounds.

There are a few modes to play such as Two headed giant that is basically 2vs2. A classic free for all mode. Last a mode called plane chase that have a extra set of cards where these cards may turn the whole situation upside down by giving all creatures to given player flying or extra creatures.

Oh, and you don’t need to buy card packs in this game as you will unlock cards as you play. You can also unlock everything for a set price if you want, but it is not necessary.

Last! Don’t buy this game if you don’t have any friends that play the 2013 edition as there is just a few to none players online.

Cons:

Magic: The gathering – Duels of the Planewalkers2013 is a fun competitive card game to play with friends. Especially when there are four players in the game as it makes it a whole lot more dynamic and you won’t necessary loose just because you got badly RNG’d from the start.

The game consists of a Champaign that works pretty well where you will fight each deck to unlock them. There are also encounters such as fighting the hydra. Each encounter has a different touch to them, such as the hydra it gains attack/health for each turn.
When you have beaten the game you unlock the revenge campaign that upper the difficulty if you found the first campaign too easy.
There is also a challenge mod (that actually is challenging!) where you are presented by different scenarios and have to win the game within a set number of rounds.

There are a few modes to play such as Two headed giant that is basically 2vs2. A classic free for all mode. Last a mode called plane chase that have a extra set of cards where these cards may turn the whole situation upside down by giving all creatures to given player flying or extra creatures.

Oh, and you don’t need to buy card packs in this game as you will unlock cards as you play. You can also unlock everything for a set price if you want, but it is not necessary.

Last! Don’t buy this game if you don’t have any friends that play the 2013 edition as there is just a few to none players online.

Pros:
- Fun with friends
- Challanging
- Don’t need buy cards

Cons:
- Prepare to get RNG’d
- Short campaign
- Few players online
